body:
Actually, since commit 31901bc862db60878130fcd9cbf9c4895d41b2d2, new before_save callbacks have been added which reset the token in the [recoverable module](https://github.com/plataformatec/devise/blob/master/lib/devise/models/recoverable.rb)

```
if email_changed? || encrypted_password_changed?
    clear_reset_password_token
end
```

This only makes sense for database_authenticable models. In my case, I'm using LDAP authentication with Mongoid and I don't have a `encrypted_password` field, therefore the `encrypted_password_changed?` method isn't generated for my model, and causes crashes pretty much everywhere.

A quick fix would be to add the field `encrypted_password` even if it's never going to be used.

@Startouf yup, that is it. I could push a fix but... how can you reset the password if you don't have a password? Or do you mean you have a reset password and a password reset process, it is just that it is not stored in the DB?

Yeah I'm using the `ldap_authenticable` gem [from cschiewek](https://github.com/cschiewek/devise_ldap_authenticatable) which basically handles all the authentication against a remote LDAP server.

I don't know how it works internally, but on the readme they mention an option

> ldap_update_password (default: true)
>    When doing password resets, if true will update the LDAP server. Requires admin password in > the ldap.yml

So I yes I guess there's a password reset process behind, and the password is not saved on the DB but on the remote LDAP ^^
Awesome! Do you want to send a pull request that adds a respond_to? check or should I go ahead? Thanks for reporting!

I have the same problem, I'm not using the `database_authenticatable` module in favor of implementing the authentication via JWT and Rails `has_secure_password`

I'm using the recoverable, confirmable, and validatable modules and it's working great with 3.4.1 but updating to 3.5.1 caused everything to error...

IMHO I think you should check if the model is `database_authenticatable` then check for `encrypted_password_changed?` which I think will work on all weird cases ( like the case I have )

Same problem with email_changed?. I don't have an email field, but use mobile number instead for authentication, so email_changed? will be undefined. I see this line in devise.rb: 

```
config.authentication_keys = [ :email ]
```

It can be a good idea to find out which key is used for authentication and check whether it is changed from there. I would love to send a pull request if anyone can give me a bit guidance on how to do that.

Sorry, I have been busier than usual, can someone add a flag with the relevant `respond_to?(:...)` checks? For the email case though, we should probably traverse authentication_keys looking for changes.

I'm also getting this error after trying to upgrade from 3.4.1 to 3.5.6.
Almost as @artmees, I only use the recoverable module from devise and use the `has_secure_password` from Rails. Any updates on this? I would really like to upgrade to at least 3.5.4 for the [CVE-2015-8314](http://blog.plataformatec.com.br/2016/01/improve-remember-me-cookie-expiration-in-devise/) fix .

issue.title: [#114723195] upgrade rubygems

repository.name: webservices
repository.description: DEPRECATED The project facilitates exposing data sets through APIs

issue.body:
- Lock devise at 3.4.x to work around https://github.com/plataformatec/devise/issues/3624
- More config required for shoulda-matchers v3
- Tweaks to text processing and specs to account for bump from Sanitize 2.x to 4.x
- Move Airbrake out of development group; won't work for v5 without project ID/key

issue.title: NoMethodError in Devise::CasSessionsController#service
issue.body:
I am trying out cas authentication in the Rails 5 beta 3 release, but I keep running into this error when I attempt to do anything that handles authentication.

```
undefined method `encrypted_password_changed?' for #<AdminUser:0x0000000676d508>
```

What should I define to fix the `encrypted_password_changed?` error?
